Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 39288  
June 2007 
 
 
 
Seminars on Capacity Building for Project 
Implementation and Administration  
for 2007–2009 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  COSO  –  Central Operations Services Office 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  EA  –  executing agency 
  PIU  –  project implementation unit 
  RD  –  regional department 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  RM  –  resident mission 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Governance, regional cooperation, and capacity development  
Subthemes  –  Public governance, anticorruption 
 
 
NOTE 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Vice President, Operations 2 
Principal Director   P. Daltrop, Central Operations Services Office 
Director  R. Marshall, Central Operations Services Division 1 
  I. Santoso, Central Operations Services Division 2 
 
Team leader  C. Valbuena, Senior Procurement Specialist, Central Operations 
Services Division 1

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Improved project implementation and administration constitute a focus of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and its borrowers. Since 1978, the regional and country project 
implementation and administration seminars funded by ADB technical assistance (TA) grants 
have  helped  borrowers  and  their  executing  agencies  (EAs)  strengthen  their  capacities  to 
manage project implementation. Senior and middle-level officials of EAs, central ministries, 
state  banks,  and  state  and  provincial  governments  from  34  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs) have participated in these seminar programs covering the procurement of goods, works 
and  consulting  services,  as  well  as  disbursement.  This regional  TA  (RETA)1 aims  to  hold 
country  seminars  in  approximately  nine  DMCs,  two  subregional  seminars,  and  a  regional 
seminar at ADB headquarters in the period July 2007 to June 2009. The RETA framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Country portfolio review missions and regular project supervision missions continue to 
observe that delays in project implementation are largely caused by a lack of understanding of 
and  unfamiliarity  with  ADB’s  requirements  and  guidelines.  There  is  a  continuing  need  for 
training for EA and staff of project implementing units (PIU), with a program designed to meet 
the needs of both ongoing and new projects, as well as provide different levels of skills. DMCs 
also  appreciate  that  familiarity  with  ADB  procedures  will  ultimately  lead  to  better  project 
implementation that avoids or reduces delays, leading to early delivery of project benefits and 
savings in commitment charge payments. 
 
3.  This  RETA  is  designed  to  address  deficiencies  in  project  implementation  and 
administration by upgrading or updating the skills of EA and PIU personnel in an adaptable and 
flexible manner. The training will (i) familiarize participants from new EAs and PIUs with the 
ADB Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time), Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time); ADB disbursement procedures, and other 
associated subjects in project administration; and (ii) train other officials from EAs that may have 
administered ADB-assisted projects but may need to transfer and replace staff of ongoing ADB-
assisted projects, or acquire new staff for new projects, or both.  
 
4.  The RETA supports capacity-building, particularly in fulfilling two objectives: institution 
strengthening and human resource development. The training programs indirectly support other 
governance strategies on improved accountability, transparency, and anticorruption efforts. 
 
5.  Evaluation and feedback from seminars indicate that the training programs strengthen 
participants' professional skills and increase their understanding of ADB’s requirements for 
project implementation and administration. Past lessons learned from these seminars have led 
to amendments to clauses in the standard bidding documents, as well as to changes in the 
content and focus of case studies and exercises in seminars. The seminars’ structure and 
content are continually revised and improved on the basis of suggestions from participants and 
in response to the changing needs of EAs and ADB.  
 
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 18 May 2006.

2   
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The seminars will enable project directors, managers, and other key staff members of 
EAs, PIUs, and other government counterpart agencies to develop the required proficiency in 
project implementation and administration following ADB policies and procedures. The seminars 
will provide tools and information on ADB's guidelines and procedures in procuring goods and 
works,  selecting  and  engaging  consultants,  and  making  disbursements.  The  new  stock  of 
knowledge gained by personnel and officials will upgrade the implementing capacity of EAs and 
DMCs in general. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  It is estimated that nine country seminars on project implementation and administration, 
two subregional seminars (possibly for the Pacific and Central Asian DMCs), and one regional 
seminar to be held at headquarters will be conducted. The seminars will have similar formats, 
schedules, and content. New methods of delivering the seminar content will be adopted based 
on the results of the pilot test undertaken in the previous RETA. These will be more interactive, 
with greater use of the Internet, when feasible. As an option to the traditional “component-
based” seminar where the modules and topics involve general discussions of procurement, 
consultant selection, and disbursement procedures, the seminar program  may  be “project-
based,”  i.e.,  the  same  topics  are covered  but  the  cases  and  exercises  are  focused  on  a 
particular project or group of projects in the host DMC. The factors that will be considered in 
tailoring the program and mix, subjects and durations of lectures and case studies to the 
specific country and regional seminars are the profile and capacity of participants, the types of 
procurement planned, and the implementation issues currently faced by or expected from the 
participating project or projects. 
 
8.  The nine country seminars, each lasting 6 to 9 days, will be conducted in DMCs (i) 
where  loans  approved  in  2006  and  2007  involved  or  will  involve  new  EAs  and  PIUs,  (ii) 
receiving a large number of loans annually, (iii) that requested inclusion, and (iv) that need the 
seminar  as  a  result  of  analyses  undertaken  during  project  review  missions.  The  target 
participants are project managers and middle-level project staff. The seminars will be flexible in 
terms of modules and size of participation, as well as the time schedule. Subject to midyear and 
year-end  reviews,  the  country  seminars  are  expected  to  be  held  in  Cambodia,  People’s 
Republic of China, India, Indonesia, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, Sri Lanka, and Uzbekistan. 
 
9.  The seminars will be conducted in English, and combine lectures, case studies, group 
discussions,  workshops,  and  practical  exercises.  They  will  address  the  responsibilities  of 
managers and other key project officials in project implementation, including pre-implementation 
activities  of  project  packaging  and  procurement  planning,  start-up  activities  of  consultant 
selection and procurement, and the critical implementation concern of disbursement. The scope 
and content will include discussion of issues and situations that arise in relation to these 
activities, as well as good practices in evaluation methods and decision making. The case 
studies will analyze problem situations and the decision-making process. The class exercises 
will test and reinforce the participants' abilities to apply implementation tools and techniques in 
relation to the types of projects assisted by ADB.  Quizzes and short tests will be incorporated 
into the programs.

3
10.  The subregional and regional seminars will follow the same format and schedule as the 
country seminars, but may offer additional presentations to the extent that ADB headquarters 
and resident mission (RM) staff resources are available. The regional seminar will also take 
from 6 to 9 days, and newly appointed project directors and senior policy makers of central 
agencies will form the target group.  
 
11.  The major risk that will continue to be faced by the program is the retention of the trained 
staff in the PIUs, as it is not unusual for these trained officials to be placed in more senior 
administrative duties after initial success in their technical duties. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.   The total cost of the RETA is estimated at $800,000 equivalent, which will support the 
nine country seminars, and the regional and subregional seminars. The detailed cost estimates 
are shown in Appendix 2. The RETA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding 
program. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Central Operations Services Office (COSO) will be responsible for implementing the 
RETA. Nominations for participation will be solicited from ADB’s regional departments (RDs) 
and RMs. A list of ADB-recommended nominees will then be submitted to the governments for 
consideration  and  endorsement.  Acceptance  of  additional  nominations  proposed  by  the 
governments will be subject to confirmation by ADB. 
 
14.  Apart  from  identifying  the  participants,  RMs  will  provide assistance in  selecting  the 
venue  and  negotiating  contractual  terms  for  use  of  the  selected  venue.  By  opening  the 
seminars, RMs and the guest officials from the counterpart government agencies also can guide 
the ADB resource persons to any particular emphasis among the seminar topics that should be 
taken, to the extent possible. Counterpart government agencies or RMs/RDs may also request 
special topics to be inserted into the seminar schedule such as a discussion on the national 
procurement  laws,  regulations,  and  procedures.  A  typical  seminar  program  is  shown  in 
Appendix 3. 
 
15.  Invitations will be extended to project directors and managers and to other key staff from 
the EAs of ADB-assisted projects, particularly those at the inception stage. Participation of 
selected policy makers from central agencies involved in formulating financial and procurement 
regulations will be encouraged. About 30 to 40 participants for each seminar will be selected. 
RETA activities are expected to start in the third quarter of 2007 and be completed by the 
second quarter of 2009. The resource persons for the country and regional seminars will be 
from ADB, particularly procurement specialists from COSO and financial control specialists from 
the Controller’s Department. Specialists from other departments may be invited for special 
topics, e.g., the Office of the Auditor General (OAG) for an anticorruption module.  
 
16.  A no-objection letter will be obtained prior to starting or financing the RETA activities in 
the territory of the participating DMCs. Postseminar feedback from participants and resource 
persons will be provided to the DMCs through the RMs.

4   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
the Seminars on Capacity Building for Project Implementation and Administration for 2007–
2009, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
